course_title: Freshman Seminar: World History of Railways
class_notes:
(Freshmen Only)


Steam-powered railways were invented in the early 1800s and made it possible, for the first time in world history, to carry people and goods overland at high speed. They played a central part in the industrial revolutions of Britain, Europe, and the United States.  In the twentieth century they were adapted to much greener technology; Japanese and French electric trains have been running at 200 miles per hour since the 1960s, and a Chinese mag-lev train now runs at over 300.  This course will trace the development of railways around the world along with their social, political, and economic effects.  Requirements: class participation, two papers, a midterm, and a final.
course_description: Introduces first-year students to the discipline of history, particularly historical sources and methods; aims to improve critical reading, analytical, and writing skills in small group discussion.
